Option D. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, also does not interact significantly with antiretroviral therapy and is not the drug that needs to be changed in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HIV and TB cotreatment:

 

  • If a person is on the TLE regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, efavirenz), it does not interact with rifampicin. The regimen can continue unchanged even if rifampicin is given.
  • If the person is on the TLD regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, dolutegravir), the dose of dolutegravir should be doubled when rifampicin is used, while the rest of the regimen remains the same.
  • If the person is taking a protease inhibitor or nevirapine, rifampicin should be avoided. Instead, rifampicin should be replaced with rifabutin.

questions.text: For OME, Myringotomy is done in which quadrant? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antero-inferior

 

Explanation:

 

In Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), myringotomy is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. This location is specifically chosen because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding important structures. The antero-inferior quadrant is the safest area to make an incision as it avoids damage to the ossicles and other vital middle ear structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antero-posterior: No such quadrant exists.

 

Option C. Postero-superior: This is the most dangerous quadrant for myringotomy as it contains the incus and stapes. Additionally, the chorda tympani nerve runs through this area, and facial nerve injury is a risk if the incision extends too deeply. This area is avoided for routine myringotomy.

 

Option D. Postero-inferior: Although this quadrant is relatively safe compared to the postero-superior quadrant, it is not the preferred site for myringotomy. The round window niche is located in the posterior part of the middle ear, and damage to this structure could potentially affect inner ear function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringotomy for OME is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding vital middle ear structures, ensuring both effectiveness and safety of the procedure.

questions.text: It is being planned to put posters in the whole city for health promotion. Which type of health education approach is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mass based

 

Posters are a type of mass-based health education approach. Health education approaches can be divided into three main categories:

 

  • Individual-based methods (like interpersonal communication, personal letters, home visits)
  • Group-based methods (like lectures, focus group discussions, panel discussions)
  • Mass-based methods (like posters, television, radio, newsprint, banners, charts)

 

Posters placed throughout a city reach a large audience simultaneously and are therefore classified as a mass-based approach to health education.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Individual based: Incorrect as individual-based approaches involve one-on-one interactions like personal counseling or home visits 

 

Option B. Group-based: Incorrect as group-based approaches involve interactive sessions with specific groups like lectures or workshops 

 

Option D. One to one: Incorrect as this is a form of individual communication and not suitable for city-wide health promotion through posters

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Posters are a mass-based health education approach used for reaching large populations simultaneously with health messages.

 

Approaches For Health Communication

questions.text: A person missing from home is found wandering purposefully. He is well-groomed and denies having any amnesia. Most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Dissociative fugue

 

Explanation:

 

Dissociative fugue is marked by sudden, unexpected travel away from home or familiar surroundings. During a fugue, individuals often appear well-groomed and behave in a seemingly normal, goal-directed way, which reflects preserved self-care and orientation. However, once the fugue ends, they usually experience amnesia for what occurred during the episode. While in the fugue state, they might not even recognize anything is wrong and may deny memory issues. These episodes can last from minutes to months, and some individuals may have recurrent fugues. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue is considered a specifier of dissociative amnesia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Dissociative amnesia: This involves an inability to recall important personal information, usually related to trauma or stress, but it does not necessarily  include the travel or wandering behavior seen in fugue states. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue has been made a subtype of dissociative amnesia. 
  • Option C. Schizophrenia: People with schizophrenia may wander, but it’s typically disorganized or bizarre rather than purposeful. There are other signs also  like hallucinations, delusions, or negative symptoms. The person’s well-groomed appearance and coherent behavior is  against this diagnosis.
  • Option D. Dementia: Wandering can happen in dementia, but the onset is usually gradual, and the person often appears disheveled or confused. Dementia-related wandering stems from memory loss and impaired judgment, not dissociation. Plus, the sudden nature described in this case doesn't fit with how dementia typically presents.

 

Educational Objective:


If someone suddenly leaves home and ends up in a new place with intact self-care, normal-seeming behavior, and later has no memory of it, it must be dissociative fugue—especially if there are no psychotic or neurocognitive symptoms present.

choices.text: Barrier methods for 4 months and then Semen analysis to confirm
Barrier methods for 3 months and then Semen analysis to confirm
Barrier methods for 4 months with no need to come back
Barrier methods for 3 months with no need to come back

questions.text: Which of the following guidelines are true for the client post-vasectomy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barrier methods for 3 months and then Semen analysis to confirm

 

After vasectomy, a person is not immediately sterile. It takes 3 months for spermatozoa to clear from the reproductive tract. During this period, the client must use barrier methods of contraception. After 3 months, semen analysis should be done to confirm the success of sterilization.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-vasectomy guidelines require:

 

  1. Use of barrier methods for 3 months
  2. Mandatory semen analysis after 3 months to confirm success of sterilization

questions.text: Endolymphatic hydrops is typically associated with which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Meniere's disease

 

Explanation: 

 

Endolymphatic hydrops is the pathophysiological basis of Meniere's disease. It is characterized by excessive accumulation of endolymph in the inner ear, causing distension of the membranous labyrinth. This directly correlates with the classic clinical symptoms seen in Meniere's disease: episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus and aural fullness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: This is a condition with irregular spongy bone formation around the oval window, leading to fixation of the stapes footplate. It causes a conductive hearing loss due to impeded sound transmission. Otosclerosis has no relationship with endolymphatic hydrops or the balance mechanism.

 

Option C. Acoustic Neuroma: This is a benign tumor that arises from the inferior vestibular nerve in the internal auditory canal. It causes progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. It is not associated with endolymphatic hydrops or fluctuating symptoms like those seen in Meniere's disease.

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma: This is a "skin in the wrong place" - keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear cleft. It causes a destructive process in the middle ear with bone erosion and conductive hearing loss. It has no connection with endolymphatic hydrops.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Endolymphatic hydrops is the hallmark pathological finding in Meniere's disease, causing episodic symptoms of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and aural fullness due to increased pressure in the inner ear's endolymphatic system.
